posts.name: $. Jazzwal
posts.cooked:
Hi, I am one of two programmers from team 4980 - a team of 14 students, mostly underclassmen. Our team comes from a rural community, and we lack the humanpower and resources larger teams have to trial and error, or research, our way to a solution to our problem, so I figured I would ask the FIRST community for guidance. As common with a software sub-team, we got a â€œworkingâ€ robot to program this week - we are competing at PNW Sammamish this weekendâ€‹:wink:

We are trying to write code to â€œsquareâ€ and align our robot with any April tag our Limelight sees (Limelight 4). So far we have been using the â€œtxâ€ values to strafe the cross hairs of the limelight to the center of the target and the â€œapriltag IDsâ€ to hard code April tag angles using field relative pointing down field, with variable successðŸ˜…

Is there any way to get the angle of the April tag and dynamically update and compare the Apriltagâ€™s angle relative to the robot in order to rotate the robot so that the April tag is square with it, while strafing to ensure the â€œtxâ€ value remains zero and therefore aligning it with the tag? are there any vision libraries available that allow this functionality? or are we going about this wrong and we should try a different approach? Any advice, suggestions, code, or help would be greatly appreciated

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Do you have a gyro on the robot? You can look up a gyro heading for each tag in code and then turn to that angle. Then once you are close enough to that heading, tx should be â€œclose enoughâ€ to align left/right

posts.name: $. Jazzwal
posts.cooked:
Yea, that is what we have been doing - but we have run into the issue (sorry if this is confusing, I am not good at explaining itðŸ˜…) where the robotâ€™s strafe and attempt to rotate at the same time results in the robot moving away from the April tag and rotating towards it - which makes the April tag out of view.

like imagine the robot turned off-angle with the crosshairs on the left and the April tag on the right - the robot tries to strafe and turn to angle at the same time, causing it to strafe away from the April tag and rotate until the April tag is out of view

This is why we are trying to track the April tag by centering the robot using the tx value and dynamically aligning to the angle the April tag is at in relation to the robot

Take a look on the post i made here in a similar topic it has an example from our code aligning using the tx tz and rotation

How to Align Precisely Using Limelight TX with YAGSL? Programming

link_counts.title: How to Align Precisely Using Limelight TX with YAGSL?
I can't find reliable aiming code for limelight in Java

posts.cooked: Notice that you need to set your limelight to 3D otherwise it wont work

posts.name: $. Jazzwal
posts.cooked:
Oh thank you!! I took a look at your code and (again bear with me as I am a relatively new programmer) I was wondering what specifically the code is supposed to do - is it meant to align with any April tag by strafing to get the â€œtxâ€ value to zero using the PID input, or does it also rotate the robot to match the angle of the April tag?

And thanks for the heads up on using the Pose 3d, we were trying with Pose 2d so that definitely may have been one of our issuesðŸ˜…

The code aligns in all 3 axis x y and rotation to the tag

But it has to see the tag meaning you have to look at the tag than press the button to align

The code aligns to the closest tag it sees(you need to set it in the limelight interface shown how in the second thread) this means if it accidentally sees a wrong tag it will just drive to it

During testing had a few times the driver was a bit off and the robot saw a diffrent tag than we expected and the robot drove and alignd to that tag

Also when i said you need to use 3d i didnt ment 3dPose in the code, in the limelight interface in one of the tabs(i think in the advanced) there is an option called use 3d tag data somthing like that you need to turn it on What this option does is making the limelight return you its position from the tag in meter and degrees insted of angles

Chat gpt gives a pretty good explanation to the code:

The code uses three PID controllers:

One for controlling the robotâ€™s movement along the X-axis (forward and backward).

One for controlling the movement along the Y-axis (side to side).

One for controlling the rotation (turning to face the right direction).

At the beginning of the code, we set the setpoints for each PID . The setpoint is the desired position or angle that the robot should reach. This means that when the robot is fully aligned, its X, Y, and rotation values should match these setpoints.

Initialization ( initialize method)

Starts two timers: One checks how long the robot hasnâ€™t seen a tag. The other checks how long the robot has been correctly aligned.

One checks how long the robot hasnâ€™t seen a tag.

The other checks how long the robot has been correctly aligned.

Sets the target positions (setpoints) for the three PID controllers.

Executing the alignment ( execute method)

If the Limelight camera detects a tag, it: Resets the â€œdonâ€™t see tagâ€ timer. Reads the robotâ€™s position from the Limelight. Uses the PID controllers to calculate how fast the robot should move forward/backward, left/right, and rotate. Moves the robot using these calculated speeds. If the robot is not yet aligned, it resets the alignment timer.

Resets the â€œdonâ€™t see tagâ€ timer.

Reads the robotâ€™s position from the Limelight.

Uses the PID controllers to calculate how fast the robot should move forward/backward, left/right, and rotate.

Moves the robot using these calculated speeds.

If the robot is not yet aligned, it resets the alignment timer.

If the Limelight does not see a tag, the robot stops moving.

Stopping the robot ( end method)

When the command ends, it tells the robot to stop moving.

Checking if the robot is finished ( isFinished method)

The command stops when: The robot has not seen a tag for a certain amount of time. The robot has stayed correctly aligned for a certain amount of time.

The robot has not seen a tag for a certain amount of time.

The robot has stayed correctly aligned for a certain amount of time.
!!NOTICE that when aligning you need to use robot relative driving not field relative

posts.name: $. Jazzwal
posts.cooked: We have been breaking down your code and are planning on implementing some of it tonight to see if it works for our solution thank you for all of your help and in-depth explanation!!

posts.name: $. Jazzwal
posts.cooked: Oh, that is good to knowâ€‹:+1:t5: We are using Advantage Kit, which I think is different from YAGSL , so we might need more digging to find a good robot relative method to use when plugging and chugging our PID values :)

posts.name: $. Jazzwal
posts.cooked: If anyone else has any other vision concepts or recommendations for squaring and aligning with the reef using April tags, please let us know in this thread, this is our first year using vision as a very small, rural team, so any help is greatly appreciated

wrote a better more in depth post of how to align using this way with the limelight you can check it out https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/from-zero-to-auto-align-to-reef-tutorial-how-to-simply-auto-align-to-the-reef/494478?u=kully
